header.annotationScheme: Guidelines for the syntactic annotation of the Ancient Greek dependency treebank 1.1

respStmt.resp: release editor: post-annotation normalization and harmonization
responsible for the annotation environment and cts:urn technology

monogr.author: Aeschylus
monogr.title: Aeschylus, with an English translation by Herbert Weir Smyth, Ph. D. in two volumes. 1.Suppliant Women

imprint.publisher: Cambridge, Mass., Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann, Ltd.

header.encodingDesc: The unannotated text comes from the digital edition of the text specified in the element monogr. The digital edition can be consulted on PerseusDL (https://github.com/PerseusDL/canonical-greekLit), looking up the cts:urn. The annotator(s) may have chosen different variants for the text.
header.profileDesc: Consult the file README.xml for the details concerning normalization and harmonization of the text, and the file TAGSETS.xml for the meaning of the labels used in the annotation. The treebanked text before normalization and harmonization can be consulted on PerseusDL (https://github.com/PerseusDL/treebank_data/tree/master/v1.6).

sentence.translation: May Zeus, protector of suppliants, look kindly upon our naval company, having set out from the fine-sanded mouths of the Nile.

And leaving the divine land bordering Syria we flee, not exiled by a public vote of the city for bloodshed, but by self-imposed flight from men, abhorring the impious marriage of the sons of Aegyptus.

And Danaus, father and counselor and faction-leader, arranging these things, decided on the most glorious of griefs, to flee freely through the salt wave, and to land at the land of Argos, from where indeed our race, claiming descent from the touch and breath of Zeus on the gadfly-driven cow, has been derived.
To what land then more kindly than this could we come with these wands of suppliants, wool-wreathed branches?

O city, O land, and white water, and high gods, and heavy-avenging powers possessing the graves below, and Zeus Savior third, guardian of the house of pious men, receive this female suppliant company with a reverent spirit of the land.
But the swarm of insolent males, Egypt-born, before placing foot on this silty land, with their swift chariot send into the sea.

And there, meeting with a storm-beaten hurricane, with thunder and lightning and rain-bearing winds of the wild sea, may they perish, before ever appropriating the beds from which law bars them, and mounting this cousinhood unwilling.
And now invoking the divine calf, the avenger from beyond the sea, and the son of the flower-grazing ancestress cow, from the breath of Zeus, the touch...
And by the name the fated time was fulfilled reasonably, and she begot Epaphus;

And invoking him, now in the grass-grazing places of my ancient mother, remembering her former toils, I shall show forth now faithful proofs to the inhabitants, and other things, though being unexpected, shall appear.
And someone will know the tale in time.
But if there chance to be any native augur near, hearing the lament, he will think that he hears the voice of the wife of Tereus, wailing Metis, the hawk-chased nightingale,
who, driven from green leaves, laments her home,
and composes the doom of her child, how he perished by his own kin, meeting with the wrath of an unnatural mother.
Even so I too, fond of lamenting in Ionian strains, tear my soft, Nile-warmed cheek and my heart unacquainted with tears.
And I cull the flowers of grief, fearing my friends, lest there be some protector of this flight from the hazy land.
But, gods ancestral, hear well, beholding justice;
not granting to youth to have fulfillment beyond destiny, but hating hubris readily, you would be just in regard to marriage.
And even for those fleeing hard pressed from war, there is an altar, a defense against harm, held in awe by the gods.
May everything be truly well from Zeus.
The desire of Zeus is not easily hunted.
Truly it blazes everywhere, even in the dark, with black fortune for mortal peoples.
And it falls safe, not on its back, if a matter is fulfilled by the nod of Zeus.
For the paths of his mind stretch thick and shady, unperceived to look upon.
He hurls mortals to utter destruction from their high-towered hopes, and he arms no violence;
all that is of the gods is effortless.
Sitting, he accomplishes his thought in some way from there, nevertheless from his holy seat.

But let him look upon mortal hubris, how it grows young, a stock flowering through my marriage with thoughts hard to counsel, and having a frenzied purpose as an inescapable goad, and changing its mind by deception to ruin.
Shrieking such piteous sufferings, I speak shrill, heavy, tear-falling things, ie ie, befitting laments;
alive, I honor myself with wailings.
I implore the Apian hill, and you know well the barbarian speech, O earth;
and often I fall with a rending of my linen-destroying Sidonian veil.
And to the gods pure rites are paid, accruing well where death is absent.
Oh, oh, oh, troubles are hard to determine!
Where will this wave carry us away?
I implore the Apian hill, and you know well the barbarian speech, O earth.
and often I fall with a rending of my linen-destroying Sidonian veil.
The oar indeed, and the flax-stitched house of wood keeping out the sea, sent me, untroubled by storms, with the breezes;
nor do I complain;
And may the all-seeing father bring about propitious ends for me in time,
so that the great seed of a holy mother may escape the beds of men, ah ah, unwedded, untamed.

And may the pure daughter of Zeus look upon me, willing upon one willing, holding her holy face securely, and with all strength, grieving at our persecutions, may she come as a virgin deliverer to virgins.
so that the great seed of a holy mother may escape the beds of men, ah ah, unwedded, untamed.
But if not, a sun-burnt black race, we will approach Zeus of the Earth, the most hospitable to the dead, with branch-bearing nooses, dying by not attaining the Olympian gods.
Ah Zeus, the searching wrath from the gods [pursues] Io because of the poison/arrow.
And I know the heaven-conquering spite of a wife.
For a storm comes from a harsh wind.
And then Zeus will be liable to unjust charges, having dishonored the child of the cow, whom he himself once begot, now holding his face turned away in prayers.
But may he hear well from on high, being called upon.
Children, it is necessary to be prudent.
And you have come with a prudent, faithful old man, this ship-captain father.
And having taken forethought for matters on land now, I advise you to guard my words, recording them on tablets.
I see dust, voiceless messenger of an army.
The axle-driven naves are not silent.
And I see a shield-bearing and spear-brandishing crowd, with horses and curved chariots.
Perhaps the leaders of this land might be lookers on us, having learned from messengers.
But whether harmless or whetted with raw wrath he urges on this expedition, it is better for the sake of everything, O maidens, to sit at this mound of the assembly-gods.

And an altar is stronger than a tower, an unbreakable shield; but go as quickly as possible, and holding white-wreathed suppliant branches, ornaments of reverent Zeus, solemnly in your left hands, answer the strangers with reverent and mournful and needy words, as is fitting for foreigners, telling clearly of this bloodless flight.
And let there accompany your voice first not being bold, and let not being vain go forth from your modest-browed faces, from a quiet eye.
And do not be forward in speech nor drawling in your talk.
The race here is very prone to envy.
And remember to yield;
you are a needy foreign exile.
For it is not fitting for the weaker to be bold of speech.
Father, you speak prudently to the prudent.
And I will take care to remember these trusty commands of yours.
And may Zeus the progenitor look upon us;
may he look indeed with a propitious eye;
I would wish now to take my seat near you.
Do not delay now, but let there be success in the device.
O Zeus, pity us for our toils, before we are destroyed.
If he is willing, these things will end well.
And call now upon this bird of Zeus.
We invoke the saving rays of the sun, and holy Apollo, a god exiled from heaven.
Knowing this fate, he might sympathize with mortals.
May he indeed sympathize and stand by us kindly.
Whom then of these gods shall I call upon further?
I see this trident, a sign of the god.
But he sent us well, and may he receive us well in the land.
Here is another, Hermes, according to the customs of the Greeks.
Let him herald good tidings to free men.
But reverence the common altar of all these lords;
and sit on holy ground like a flock of doves in fear of hawks of the same feather, enemies and polluters of the race.
How can bird be pure eating bird?
And how could one be pure marrying an unwilling maid from an unwilling father?
Not even when dead in Hades would he escape the charge of lewdness, having done these things.
Even there, as the story goes, another Zeus judges sins among the dead, the last judgments.
Consider, and answer in this way, so that this affair may conquer well for you.
From what land is this company we address, not dressed in Greek attire, luxuriating in barbarian robes and thick-woven fabrics?
For this is not the Argive clothing of women, nor from Greek places.
But how you dared to come to this land fearlessly, neither announced by heralds, and without patrons, and without guides, this is a wonder.
Branches indeed lie by you according to the laws of suppliants, before the assembly gods;
In this alone the land of Greece will agree by conjecture.
And as for the rest, it would be just to conjecture much still, if a voice were not present which will signify.
You have spoken an unerring tale about my attire.
But do I speak to you as a private citizen, or a speaker with the sacred wand, or leader of the city?
Answer and speak to these things confident in me.
For I am Pelasgus, son of earth-born Palaichthon, leader of this land.
And the race of Pelasgians, rightly named after me the king, reaps this land.
and rule all the land through which the holy Strymon comes, towards the setting sun;
and I mark as my boundary the land of the Perrhaebi, and the parts beyond Pindus, near the Paeonians, and the Dodonian mountains;
and the boundary of the liquid sea cuts it short;
I rule over the parts on this side of these.
But this plain of the Apian land itself has long been named in honor of a healer man.

For Apis, coming from the district of Naupactus across the strait, healer-prophet son of Apollo, cleanses this land of man-destroying monsters, which the earth, defiled by pollution of ancient blood, sent up, wrath-caused woes, a hostile colony of dragons.
And having accomplished blamelessly cutting and releasing remedies for these things, Apis found for himself in return mention in prayers in the Argive land.
And having now proofs from me, you would both boast of our race and speak further.
The city, however, does not love long speech.
The tale is short and clear.
We boast to be Argives in race, seed of a cow fair in her children;
and I will attach all these things as true to my speech.
Incredible things you tell me to hear, O strangers, that this race of yours is Argive.
For you are more like Libyan women, and not at all like natives.
And the Nile might nurture such a plant, and the Cyprian character has been struck in female forms by male craftsmen;
And I hear that the nomadic women are such, who ride on camels with horse-like stride, dwelling in a land neighboring the Aethiopians.
And the husbandless, flesh-eating Amazons, if you were equipped with bows, I would have likened you to them intently.
But being taught, I might know this better, how your race and seed is Argive.
They say that Io once became key-holder of the house of Hera in this Argive land.
It was so, certainly, and the report prevails widely.
Is there also a story that Zeus mingled with a mortal?
And these entanglements were not hidden from Hera.
How then does this strife of the sovereigns end?
The Argive goddess made the woman a cow.
Does not Zeus approach the fair-horned cow?
They say [so], likening his form to a cow-mounting bull.
What then [does] the strong wife of Zeus [do] in response to these things?
She set the all-seeing guardian over the cow.
What sort of all-seeing sole-herdsman do you mean?
Argos, child of earth, whom Hermes slew.
What other thing then did she devise for the ill-fated cow?
A cow-driving, stinging gadfly.
Those near the Nile call it oistros.
Therefore it drove her from the land in a long course.
You have said all these things fittingly to me.
And truly she came to Canobus and to Memphis.
And Zeus begets a son by the touching of his hand.
Who then boasts to be the calf of Zeus of the cow?
Epaphus, truly named from the seizure.
[Who is] Libya, reaping the greatest plain of earth?
What other shoot of this one do you speak of yet?
Belus, having two children, father of this my father.
Tell me now this all-wise name.
Danaus, and his brother is fifty-childed.
Reveal his name also with ungrudging speech.
Knowing our ancient race, you would bring about your Argive company.
You seem indeed to me to share in this land from ancient times.
But how did you dare to leave your ancestral homes?
Do you, old in wisdom, learn from the younger by birth;
respecting the suppliant.
However, let him not see bold deeds from a holy man.
You do not sit as hearth-sharers of my house.
If the city is polluted in common, let the people in common take care to work out cures.
I would not fulfill a pledge before communicating with all these citizens concerning these things.
You are the city, you are the public.
Being an unjudged ruler, you rule the altar, the hearth of the land, with single-voting nods, and on single-sceptered thrones you determine every matter; guard against pollution.
guard against pollution.
May pollution be to my enemies, but I am not able to help you without harm.
Nor again is it gracious to dishonor these prayers.
And I am at a loss, and fear holds my heart, whether to act or not to act and take fortune.
Look upon the watcher from on high, the guardian of toilsome mortals, who sitting as suppliants to their neighbors do not obtain lawful justice.
The wrath of Zeus of Suppliants waits upon the one not softened by the wails of a sufferer.
If the sons of Aegyptus have power over you by the law of your city, claiming to be nearest of kin, who would wish to oppose these?
You must plead according to the laws of your home, that they have no authority over you.
May I never become subject to the power of males!
I mark out a flight under the stars as a remedy for a hateful marriage;
and choosing justice as an ally, judge the reverence due to the gods.
The judgment is not easy to judge;
do not choose me as judge.

I said even before that I would not do these things without the people, even though I have power, lest the people say sometime, if something not such should happen, "Honoring aliens you destroyed the city."
Zeus, the protector of kin, watches over these things regarding both sides, meting out fittingly unjust things to the bad, and holy things to the lawful;
Why, with these things weighing equally, do you regret doing justice?

There is need of deep saving thought, like a diver, to go to the bottom with a keen eye, not too drunk with wine, so that these things may end well without harm first for the city, and for ourselves, and that neither strife seize prizes, nor that we, giving you up who are seated at the seats of the gods, bring upon ourselves a heavy fellow-dweller, the all-destroying god, the Avenger, who not even in Hades frees the dead.
Doesn't it seem to need saving thought?
Consider, and be a justly pious patron;
do not betray the fugitive driven from afar by godless expulsions;
and do not see me dragged from the seats of many gods, O you who have all power of the land.
But recognize the violence of men and guard against their wrath.
May you not endure to see the suppliant dragged by force from the statues, contrary to justice, like a horse by the headbands, and the seizing of my many-woven robes.
For know;
whatever end you ordain for your children and your house, there remains for your children to pay an equal justice.
Consider these things just commands from Zeus.
And indeed I have considered.
And the ship is driven ashore here;
for without war there is every necessity to take up a great war either with these or with those, and the hull has been bolted with nautical winches as if hauled to land.
But without pain nowhere is there an end.
And although wealth may be carried off from plundered homes, another amount, greater than the loss and filling the ship with freight, might come by the grace of Zeus the Possessor;
and a tongue having shot forth unseasonable things, grievous things moving the heart to anger, might become enchanting of the word;
But that kindred blood may not come to be, it is necessary to sacrifice much and many victims to many gods, a cure for harm.
Certainly I have come into this strife; but I wish to be ignorant of evils rather than wise.
But may it turn out well, contrary to my judgment.
Hear the end of many reverent words.
I heard, and you would speak.
It shall not escape me.
I have breastbands and girdles, and fastenings of robes.
These things might perhaps be fitting for women.
From these then, know, a beautiful device -
Say what this utterance is that you will voice.
unless you undertake some pledge to this company -
What does this device of girdles accomplish for you?
To adorn these images with new tablets.
Your word is riddling;
but speak simply.
To hang ourselves from these statues of the gods as quickly as possible.
I have heard a word that lashes the heart.
You understand;
for I gave you eyes more clearly.
And in many ways matters are hard to wrestle with, and a multitude of evils comes on like a river;
and I have embarked upon this bottomless sea of ruin, not very easily crossed, and nowhere is there a harbor from evils.
For if I do not exact this debt for you, you have spoken a pollution not over-shootable.

But if again standing before the walls I shall try the issue of battle with the sons of Aegyptus, your kinsmen, how does the loss not become bitter, to stain the ground with the blood of men for the sake of women?
Nevertheless it is necessary to reverence the wrath of Zeus, the god of suppliants;
for the fear of him is highest among mortals.

Do you, aged father of these maidens, take these boughs forthwith in your arms and place them on other altars of the native gods, that all the citizens may see a sign of this arrival, and let no blame be cast on me;
for the people love to blame authority.
For perhaps someone, seeing these things, pitying, might hate the hubris of the male company, and the people might be more well-disposed to you;
for everyone bears good will to the weaker.
These things are worth many things to us, to get a reverent patron when found.
Send along attendants and guides of the natives, so that we may find the altars in front of the temples and the seats of the city-holding gods, and safety so that we may go through the city;
and the nature of our form is not uniform with yours.
For the Nile nurtures a race not like to Inachus.
Guard against confidence giving birth to fear.
And indeed someone killed a friend out of ignorance.
You may go, men;
for the stranger speaks well.
Lead the way to the city altars, seats of the gods;
and it is not right to speak much with those you meet, while leading this sailor as a suppliant of the gods.
To him you have spoken, and let him go as ordered;
but how should I act?
Where do you assign confidence to me?
Leave your boughs here, a sign of trouble.
And indeed I leave them by your hand and words.
Turn now towards this level grove.
And how could a common grove protect me?
We will not give you up to the ravages of winged creatures.
But what if to those more hostile than baneful dragons?
Let the word be auspicious to me who speaks auspiciously.
It is no wonder to be impatient from fear of mind.
Excessive fear is always ungovernable.
Do you cheer my heart both by speaking and acting.
But your father will not leave you deserted for a long time.
And I go to summon the native people, that I may make the public well-disposed;
and I will teach your father what things he ought to say.
Therefore remain here, and beseech the native gods with prayers to obtain that which you have a desire for.
And I will go to prepare these things.
And may persuasion and effective fortune follow.
King of kings, most blessed of the blessed, and most perfect power of the perfect, happy Zeus, be persuaded and ward off the hubris of men from your race, hating it well;
and cast into the purple sea the black-benched woe.
And looking upon the ancient race on the women's side, our race, renew the kindly tale of the beloved ancestress woman; become mindful of many things, O toucher of Io;
We boast to be of the race of Zeus, colonists from this land.

And I have moved to the ancient track of my mother, to the flower-grazing places of her watch, the cow-pasturing meadow, whence Io, driven by the gadfly, flees distraught, passing through many tribes of mortals; and cutting apart the wave-washed strait, she marks out the land on the opposite shore as distinct by fate.
And she darts through the land of Asia, through sheep-grazing Phrygia;

and she passes the city of Teuthras of the Mysians, and the Lydian vales, and rushing through the mountains of the Cilicians and Pamphylians, and ever-flowing rivers and deep-soiled land, and the wheat-rich land of Aphrodite.

She comes to the divine all-nourishing grove, the snow-fed meadow, which the might of Typho approaches, and the water of the Nile untouched by diseases, maddened by toils and frenzied pains and the goading stings of Hera.
And mortals, who were then inhabitants of the land, shook with pale fear in their hearts, seeing the unusual sight, a beast mixed with a mortal, part cow and part woman;
and they were amazed at the prodigy.
And who was he who then calmed the far-wandering, wretched, gadfly-driven Io?
And receiving the ballast of Zeus in true account, she bore a blameless child,
prosperous throughout a long age.
From which all the earth cries out, 'Truly this is the race of life-giving Zeus.'
For who could have stopped the plotting diseases of Hera?
This is the work of Zeus, and speaking of this race from Epaphus you would hit the mark.
Whom of the gods could I reasonably call more just in works?
The father himself, planter by his own hand, lord of the race, ancient in wisdom, great craftsman, favoring Zeus, the whole remedy.
Sitting under the rule of no one, he holds sway over the lesser of stronger ones.
He respects the power of no one sitting above him.
And the deed is present as the word, to execute quickly whatever his counselling mind brings forth.
Take courage, children.
The affairs of the natives are well.
Complete decrees of the people have been resolved.
O hail, old man, announcing dearest things to me, tell us where the end has been ratified, to what effect the prevailing hand of the people is multiplied.
It seemed good to the Argives not doubtfully, but so as to make my old heart young again;
For the air bristled with right-uplifted hands in full assembly as they ratified this decree;
that we be settlers of this land, free and unravaged, and with asylum from mortals;
and that neither native nor foreigner carry us off;
but if he applies force, that any of these landholders who does not come to aid be dishonored together with public banishment.

The king of the Pelasgians persuaded, making such a speech on our behalf, warning of the great wrath of Zeus of suppliants never to make the city fat in future time, and saying that a double pollution appearing before the city, foreign and native at once, is an irresistible feeding of ruin.
Hearing such things, the Argive people decreed without a herald that these things should be.
And the people of the Pelasgians heard the plausible turns of the demagogue;
and Zeus brought about the end.
Come then, let us speak good prayers for the Argives, rewards for good things;
and may Zeus, god of strangers, watch over the honors of the mouth of the stranger in truth, to meet with a blameless end.
Now also, O gods, born of Zeus, hear me pouring out prayers for the race;

never may wanton Ares, who reaps mortals with the ploughs of war, found this Pelasgian city, set on fire, insatiate of the cry, because they pitied us, and passed a kindly vote, and they reverence the suppliants of Zeus, this pitiable flock;
and they did not cast their vote with the men, dishonoring the quarrel of women, watching for the avenger of Zeus, and the irresistible watcher, whom no house could contain on its roof, defiling it;
and he sits heavily.
For they revere the suppliants of holy Zeus, their kin.
Therefore, at pure altars, they will please the gods.
Therefore let the jealous prayer fly forth from shaded mouths: never may a pestilence of men empty this city;
nor may strife stain the plain of the land with native corpses.
But let the flower of youth be unplucked, and may not the bed-partner of Aphrodite, mortal-destroying Ares, shear off the blossom.
And let the altars, where the old men receive guests, blaze with gifts.
Thus may the city be governed well, if they reverence great Zeus, god of strangers, most highly, who guides destiny by ancient law.
And we pray that other guardians of the land be born always, and that Artemis Hecate watch over the childbirth of women.
Nor let any man-destroying plague come upon this city, rending it, equipping Ares, dance-less, lyre-less, tear-begetting, and a shout in the land.
And may a joyless swarm of diseases settle far from the heads of the citizens.
And let Apollo Lyceus be gracious to all the youth.
And may Zeus cause the earth to yield its fruit with produce in every season.
And may the grazing cattle in the fields be prolific.
And may they obtain everything from the gods.
And may bards raise a fair-omened song at the altars.
And let a lyre-loving rumor be borne from pure mouths.
And may the people, who control the city, guard their honors steadily, a prudent rule of common counsel.
And may they grant rights to strangers based on fair covenants, before arming Ares, without woes.
And may they always honor the gods who hold the land with native, ancestral honors of laurel-bearing and ox-sacrifice.
For this reverence of parents is written third in the laws of Justice, accorded highest honor.
I praise these prudent prayers, my friends.
But you, do not fear, having heard these unexpected and new tidings from your father.
For from this sanctuary lookout I see the ship.
For, clearly visible, it does not escape my notice.
The trimmings of the sail, the side-guards of the ship, and the prow eyeing its way ahead, obeying the guiding rudder all too well, [are distinct].
And the sailors are conspicuous with their black limbs against white robes, and the other ships and the whole relieving fleet are visible.
But the flagship itself, having furled its sail, is being rowed with full stroke toward the land.
But it is necessary to look at the matter quietly and prudently, and not neglect the gods of this place.
But I will come, having taken helpers and advocates.
For perhaps a herald or an embassy might come, claimants of seizure wishing to lead [you] away.
But none of these things will be.
Do not fear them.
But nevertheless it is better, if we should be slow with aid, never to forget this protection.
Take courage.
Truly in time and on the appointed day, any mortal dishonoring the gods will pay the penalty.
Father, I am afraid, since the swift-winged ships have come.
And there is no length of time in between.
Fearful terror holds me, whether truly there is any help for me in my swift flight.
I am undone with fear, father.
Since the vote of the Argives is ratified, children, take courage, they will fight for you, I clearly know.
The race of Aegyptus is accursed and mad, and insatiate of battle.
And I speak to one who knows.
And having timber-built, dark-eyed ships, they sailed here in successful wrath with a large swarthy host.
But they will find many arms well-toughened in the heat of noon.
But do not abandon me alone.
I beseech you, father.
A woman left alone is nothing.
There is no martial spirit in her.
But they are destructive in mind and wily in counsel, with impure hearts, just like ravens, caring nothing for altars.
It would turn out well for us, children, if they should be hated by both you and the gods.
They will certainly not keep their hands off us, father, fearing these tridents and the sanctities of the gods.
But they are very arrogant, maddened with unholy rage, bold as dogs, heeding the gods not at all.
But there is a saying that wolves are stronger than dogs.
And the fruit of the papyrus does not conquer the ear of grain.
Since they have the tempers of foolish and unholy beasts, it is necessary to guard against their speed.

Truly, the dispatch of a naval host is not quick, nor is anchoring, where it is necessary to bring safety cables to land, nor do shepherds of ships feel confident in anchorages immediately, especially having come to a harborless land as the sun moves away into night.
Night is wont to bring forth distress for a wise pilot.
Thus, the disembarkation of the army would not be successful, before the ship is made confident in its mooring.
But you, be mindful, since you are afraid, not to neglect the gods.
Having procured aid.
The city will not blame an old messenger, but one young in his eloquent mind.
Oh hilly land, object of all reverence, what will we suffer?
Where in the Apian land are we to flee, if there is any dark hiding place anywhere?
May I become black smoke, bordering on the clouds of Zeus.
May I perish completely, invisible, flying up, unseen like dust, without wings.
And the evil would no longer be inescapable.
And my heart palpitates, dark-colored.
And my father's lookouts have caught me.
I am undone with fear.
I would wish to meet a fated noose in hangings, before a loathsome man draws near to this skin.
And may Hades rule me, having died before [that].

From where might there be for me a seat in the upper air, against which wet clouds turn to snow, or a bare, goat-abandoned, unpointed, lonely-minded, overhanging, vulture-haunted rock, witnessing a deep fall for me, before meeting the violence of a heart-rending marriage?
Then I do not refuse to become prey to dogs and a dinner to local birds.
For dying frees one from woeful evils.
Let death come, hitting me before the marriage bed.
What further path of escape do I cut, as a deliverer from marriage?
Shriek a heavenly voice, wailing songs, prayers to the gods.
And look upon these things somehow taking place as fulfilled, distinct, and painless for me, father, looking with just eyes upon violence not kindly.
And respect your suppliants, earth-holding, all-powerful Zeus.
For the male-produced Egyptian race, intolerable in wantonness, chasing after me, a fugitive, with a many-clamoring shout, seeks to take me by violence.
But the beam of the balance is yours entirely.
And what is accomplished for mortals without you?
Oh! Oh! Ah! Ah!
Here is the snatcher from the ship on the land.
Before [you seize me], snatcher, may you perish!
[Fragmentary] I cry out ... pain ... I reveal the noise.
I see these preludes of my violent troubles.
Eh! Eh!
Go in flight to the protection [of the altar].
Grim-minded with luxury, unbearable things on the ship and on land.
Lord of the land, stand before us.
Hurry, hurry to the boat, as fast as your feet can carry you! Or else, [there will be] tearings, tearings, and brandings, and bloody, murderous cutting off of the head.
Hurry! Hurry to the ship, you lost, lost creatures!
Would that you had perished in the wide-flowing, salty strait along with your masterly insolence and your bolt-bound ship!
[Fragmentary: Bloody ones ... to the ship ... ]
I order you to let go of your shouting, your craving, and the madness in your mind.
Alas! Alas!
Leave the sanctuary, go to the ship!
I do not respect what is unhonored and cityless.
May I never again see the cattle-nourishing water, from where the life-giving blood increases and thrives for mortals.
I am native, of deep lineage, old man.
But you shall go into the ship, quickly, willing or unwilling, forced by much violence, destroyed.
[Fragmentary: suffering evils ... destroyed by hands].
Alas! Alas!
Oh, would that you might perish miserably through the sea-flowing grove, wandering near the Sarpedonian bank, piled with sand, driven by wide winds!
Shriek and howl and call upon the gods!
For you shall not escape the Egyptian boat.
Shriek and cry out, pouring forth a song of woe more bitter still.
Oi, oi! The outrage! With which you, barking about before the land, crocodile, are teeming.
May the great Nile, who watches over you, turn you away, committing unseen outrage.
I command you to go to the two-way ship as quickly as possible.
And let no one delay.
For dragging indeed in no way respects a lock of hair.
Oi, Father! The help of the statue deludes me...
A spider carries me seaward, step by step.
A dream, a black dream! Otototoi, Mother Earth, Mother Earth! Avert the fearful cry, O father Pa, child of Earth, Zeus.
I do not indeed fear the gods here.
For they did not nurse me, nor did they grow old by my nursing.
A two-footed snake quivers nearby.
And like some viper, having bitten my foot, it holds me.
Otototoi, Mother Earth, Mother Earth! Avert the fearful cry, O father Pa, child of Earth, Zeus.
If someone does not go to the ship, having agreed to these things, a rending of the tunic will not pity the work.
We are destroyed.
We suffer unholy things, lord! Soon you will see many lords, the children of Aegyptus.
Take courage, you will not speak of anarchy.
Io! Leaders, chiefs of the city, I am being subdued.
It seems I will drag you, having torn you away by the hair, since you do not hear my words quickly.
You there, what are you doing?
From what spirit do you dishonor this land of Pelasgian men?
But do you really think you have come into a city of women?
But being a barbarian, you are too insolent toward Greeks.
And having erred in many things, you set nothing straight in your mind.
But what of these things has been done wrongly by me without justice?
First of all, you do not know how to be a guest.
And how not?
Finding my lost property, I am carrying it off.
Having spoken to what sort of local patrons?
To Hermes the Searcher, the greatest patron.
Having spoken to gods, you revere the gods in no way.
I revere the deities around the Nile.
But those here are nothing, as I hear from you?
I would take them, if someone does not take them away from me.
You would weep, if you should touch them, and not very long from now.
I heard the word, and it is in no way hospitable.
For I do not treat robbers of the gods as guests.
I would go and tell these things to the children of Aegyptus.
This is unheeded by my mind.
But so that I may tell them more clearly, knowing—for it is fitting for a herald to report each thing clearly—how and by whom deprived of a company of women, cousins, am I to say I have come?
Ares does not decide these things by means of witnesses.
And he does not resolve the quarrel by the receipt of silver.
But many things happen before that: falls of men and kickings-off of life.
Why is it necessary to tell you my name?
Learning it in time, you shall know it, both you yourself and your fellow travelers.
You might take these women, willing and with the goodwill of their minds, if indeed a pious argument should persuade them.
But such a vote has been ratified unanimously by the city, never to surrender the company of women by force.
Of these things, a nail has been driven clearly right through, so that they remain fixed.
These things are not written on tablets nor sealed in the folds of papyrus rolls, but you hear them clearly from a free-speaking tongue.
Now take yourself out of my sight as quickly as possible.
It seems we are about to undertake a new war.
May there be victory and power to the males.
But you will find the male inhabitants of this land indeed not drinking wine made from barley.
But all of you, having taken courage together with your dear attendants, go to the well-fenced city, locked by a deep device of towers.
And there are many public dwellings, and I am not housed with a small hand.
Where it is possible for you to inhabit well-prepared houses with many others;
But if it is a greater pleasure, it is possible to inhabit also separate houses.
Of these things the best and most agreeable are available; choose!
And I am your protector, and all the citizens, whose vote is now ratified.
Why do you wait for those with more authority than these?
But in return for good things, may you teem with good things, divine Pelasgian.
But send here kindly our father, courageous Danaus, provider of forethought and leader of counsel.
For his is the first prudence, [to decide] where it is necessary to inhabit dwellings and [what is] a kindly place.
Everyone is ready to speak blame against those of alien speech.
But may the best things be.
And with good repute and the unangered speech of the local people, take your stations, dear handmaidens, just as Danaus assigned a dowry of attendants to each.
O children, it is necessary to pray to the Argives, and to sacrifice and pour libations, as to Olympian gods, since they are saviors unequivocally.
And they heard from me bitterly about what was done by our kinsmen, our cousins.

And they assigned these attendants and spear-brandishers to me, so that I might have honorable rank, and might not perish by an unexpected spear-slain fate without notice, and an everlasting burden be upon the land.
Meeting with such things, it is necessary to revere gratitude from the depths of the mind as more honorable.
And inscribe these things also in addition to many other written prudent counsels of your father, that an unknown company is tested by time.
Everyone bears a ready evil tongue against a resident alien, and to speak a slander is somehow easy.
And I advise you not to shame me, possessing this bloom that turns the heads of mortals.
And tender fruit is in no way easy to guard.
Beasts and mortals desire it, why not?
And winged monsters and those that walk the earth.
Cypris announces dripping fruits... prohibiting... I will say, and every man passing by sends a beguiling arrow of the eye at the shapely beauty of virgins, overcome by desire.
Therefore let us not suffer those things for the sake of which much toil and much sea was ploughed with the ship's keel, and let us not achieve shame for ourselves and pleasure for my enemies.
And a twofold dwelling is available; Pelasgus gives one, and the city gives the other, to inhabit without payment.
These things are easy.
Only guard these commands of your father, valuing prudence more than life.
May we be fortunate in other things by the Olympian gods.
But concerning my fruit, take courage, father.
For unless something new has been planned by the gods, I will not turn aside the former path of my mind.
Go then, glorifying the blessed gods, lords of the city, both the city-holders and those who dwell around the ancient stream of the Erasinus.
And you attendants, accept the song.
And let praise possess this city of the Pelasgians, and let us no longer revere the mouths of the Nile with hymns.
But [let us revere] the rivers that pour a gentle drink through the land, having many children, soothing this soil of the earth with rich streams.
And may pure Artemis look upon our company with pity, and may marriage of Cytherea not come by force.
May this prize belong to the hateful ones.
But this kindly song does not neglect Cypris; for she has power nearest to Zeus together with Hera.
And the goddess of varied wiles is honored for her solemn works.
And Desire is present as a companion to his dear mother, and she to whom nothing is denied, enchanting Persuasion.
And a share of Aphrodite has been given to Harmonia and to the whispering path of the Loves.
But for the fugitives I fear blowing winds and evil pains and bloody wars.
Why did they achieve a fair voyage with swift pursuits?
Whatever is fated, that would happen.
The great, infinite mind of Zeus is not to be transgressed.
And may this end of marriage be as with many former women.
May great Zeus ward off an Egyptian marriage from me.
That would be best.
But you would charm the incharmable.
But you do not know the future.
